pros: I really enjoyed my time working at Cats Protection. It is a very well run organisation which does so much amazing work to help all cats in need, whether domestic or feral, healthy and young or elderly or with injuries or illnesses and also behaviour issues. It also treats its staff and volunteers very well.
cons: The pay is low however that is normal and understandable for a charity. Also I did not enjoy working weekends and bank holidays, however this is clearly necessary for the role.

review_title: Old fashioned, slow moving and closed minded
pros: Support from local community. Helping cats and owners with advice and support. Volunteers.
cons: Arrogant leadership team. No acknowledgement that there are issues with bullying and lack of inclusion. Nowhere for staff to go with complaints or to report anything of concern. No accountability. Money and resources are wasted. Communication is a continual problem.

job_title: Printer in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: Good company, recommend working there
cons: No cons , excellent company

pros: Working surrounded by lots of pictures of cats…
cons: Retail prices are high for charity shop so customers constantly moaning. A lot of pressure from upper management. Favouritism.

review_title: Amazing employer who values their employees
pros: I've honestly never worked for a company before that places so much value on your well being, that's one of the main reasons that I love working for Cats Protection. It's been so refreshing and motivating to really do my best in my job role because I can see that there are regular check ins, and my opinions are heard. My on-boarding process was a fantastic one, swift and thorough and my team have since become like a little work family. Hard work is rewarded and fantastic coaching where needed. Couldn't ask to work for a better company!
cons: Honestly there isn't any to point out at all. Rarely does this happen so CP is clearly doing something right. Excited to see where my career takes me here!

pros:
We work in teams to maintain a clean, comfortable environment for the animals in our care.
The people you work with are friendly and always willing to give a hand.
Seeing animals get adopted after caring for them for weeks is extremely rewarding.
And of course, you get to play with cats.
cons:
The work is physically demanding, having to crouch for extended periods to reach lower pens, or carry heavy litter bags.
It's dirty work and you have to be willing to accept the smells and cleaning that goes with it.

job_title: Cat Care Assistant in York, England
pros:
- Amazing team
- Good work-life balance
- Great opportunity to learn about animal welfare
- Lovely to work with animals
cons: - Nothing in my experience

job_title: Cat Care Assistant in Gildersome, England
pros:
Cats Protection will always hold a special place in my heart. It really is an amazing charity to work for, and you can tell right away how passionate the staff are at providing optimal welfare for the cats and finding them suitable homes.

* Management was very good at my centre. Booking time off and taking holiday was a breeze (however I always gave adequate notice). I felt listened to as a team member and feedback was discussed and fed up the chain. Unlike a lot of jobs, I felt like very comfortable discussing concerns and the like with my managers. They also took PMR's seriously and encouraged setting up goals for personal growth. I was booked on to all of the training courses available.

*Training: Your experience may vary depending on centre and resources; I had a lot of one-to-one guidance from other staff members in the beginning who welcomed me with open arms and showed me the day to day in detail. It did not take long to pick it up with their help. Over my time there, I had the opportunity to attend teams meetings for training. These go in to depth on various important and relevant topics to the job - it was also an chance to network and see things from another centre's point of view. Very interesting topics too.

* PPE and barrier nursing are taken very seriously - as they should be. There are no cutting corners when working at CP. In any animal boarding setting, there is a high risk of passing infectious pathogens between animals; and with a mix of healthy and vulnerable cats this is a serious threat. Fortunately CP are well aware of this, and all of the staff are very thorough. We had plenty of PPE supplies and training on orders of cleaning and awareness of fomites. I really respect the amount of effort put into maintaining this mindset.

* Co-workers: Again, this will vary from person to person and centre to centre; but during my time here I could not fault a single person. Everyone was a pleasure to work with, and I formed some strong bonds during my team here. Working towards a common, moral goals that everyone felt passionate about is a huge motivator to work together properly. Of course, there were differing ideas at times but these are discussed and a fitting consensus reached. I felt so welcome and appreciated during my time here and I wish all the best to the team going forward.

*Work-life balance: I worked four days a week - this was the contract I was offered, however it was a fitting life balance for me. The beauty of this job is looking forward to every shift. It was such a fun, rewarding job that I never woke up and begrudged going in. I easily could have worked more hours and felt content. I find the pay to be very fair for a position like this. I did not have special requests, but some of my co-workers had to do school runs in the morning, and another worked two other jobs and could only manage specific days. This was all fine and management helped work around their schedules. The company is also very generous with holidays; and I believe the longer you stay with the charity the more you will gain the following year.

* Responsibility: Obviously, mistakes will happen and you learn from them. There is a lot of risk if the job is not carried out properly however, and you need to make sure you are putting in effort to do it correctly and mindfully. I found having responsibility, and trust from my managers and team to carry out my job to be very fulfilling. I have gained confidence not only from this, but from helping to train volunteers and from dealing with the public. This job offers a lot in terms of personal development and growth and I know the experience will stick with me, what I have learned will aid me greatly on my future ventures.

*Exercise: Depends on what role you take on and which section of the charity you work for. I was on the ground, taking care of the cats. You will be on your feet for most of the day, lifting and bending and stretching. Deep cleans can be particularly tiring as we had very big pens. I enjoyed this aspect though, if you value 'getting your steps in' or keeping active and you would like to do that whilst you work then this job is awesome for that!

* Cats: One of the best parts of the job was the interaction with cats. We have so many coming in and out, you really get to see so many quirky personalities and learn a lot about cat behaviour in practice. You will meet some of the most loving ex-strays, nervous multi-household cats, mothers and kittens, sometimes aggressive or temperamental cats. You will meet sick cats that need a little more effort to safe guard, and you will also face heartbreak in some sad cases. You get to play a part in making these cats comfortable, seeing positive shifts in their personality, helping socialise kittens and setting them up for the rest of their lives. Yes, volunteers get more one on one time playing and cuddling with them and actually working here means you will see them a little less, during cleaning, feeding and medication etc. but being in so frequently you really do get to know them. It was amazing. Seeing these cats go from scared and shy, to falling in love with a new owner is incredibly rewarding.
cons:
My centre was split across two sites. It can be a little difficult coordinating supplies, passing information and driving to two separate places at times.

Whilst the online system was good, at times it was impossible to access. Couple that with poor wifi signal on site and it could be frustrating trying to organise the paperwork aspect of things.

Sometimes, hearing what the cats background and what they have been through can be very upsetting and it's easy to get angry about it. Of course everyone was amicable with the public, but if you cannot keep calm and deal with it appropriately this may not be the role for you.

Limited options for job progression.

pros: Freedom to merchandise the shop layout and displays. Staff discount. Set hours.
cons:
Extremely challenging to juggle managing shop operations, marketing, managing and training a team of 25 volunteers, meeting kpi's and taking your own break. 
Online selling is a high expectation which takes a lot of time listing and packaging items. Have to use personal eBay account and own bank account resulting in mixing shop money with own personal finances. Also expected to set up a personal facebook account to create and manage a shop page.

pros: It is nice to work for a good cause
cons: Very poor quality of management, no support, no communication, no recognition. Just demands. I left, not heard a word from my manager since I handed in my notice, not a thank you, not a goodbye, but a compulsory request to all shop managers to write a goodbye note for the retail manager who's leaving. This sums up working for cats protection. I am very disappointed.

job_title: Cat Care Assistant in Saint Helens, North West England, England
pros: Taking care of the cats
cons: The manager has a terrible attitude and has been the cause of many staff leaving. She has also had complaints from the general public but she has somehow kept her position. I was discriminated against after taking time off with a depressive episode and after returning to work I was told I could no longer be trusted to do my usual hours. After taking it further, my grievance and appeal were dismissed as she lied about what she said to me and her word was taken over mine. The deputy also flippantly and disrespectfully told me I should start counselling to cheer me up.

job_title: Retail Area Manager in Exeter, England
pros: I joined recently after 25 years in commercial retail and so far the experience has been fantastic. The recruitment and selection process was well organised and professional, I have had a detailed and comprehensive induction programme covering all aspects of my role and the charity. Everyone I have met has been extremely welcoming and can't do enough to help and support. I wasn't sure about making the change change to charity after so many years in commercial retail but am delighted that I did. If you're considering doing the same then I can't recommend it enough.
cons: I haven't found any so far.

review_title: I love my job for the first time ever!
pros: The staff are all so compassionate, friendly and welcoming. I love the variety of the role, it keeps it interesting and engaging. I love the satisfaction I get from sending Cat’s to loving homes and helping people in need.
cons: The term ‘receptionist’ really does not cover what this job entails, it is a really diverse role and can sometimes involve emotionally distressing conversations with people relinquishing their cats.
